text: In Greek mythology, Phoebe (; Ancient Greek: Φοίβη Phoibe, associated with Phoebos or "shining") was the name or epithet of the following characters: * Phoebe (Titaness), one of the Titans, grandmother of Apollo and Artemis.Hesiod, Theogony 116-138. Also called Selene. * Phoebe, a hamadryad, one of Danaus' many wives or concubines and possible mother of some of these Danaïdes: Hippodamia, Rhodia, Cleopatra, Asteria, Glauce, Hippomedusa, Gorge, Iphimedusa and Rhode.Pseudo-Apollodorus. Bibliotheca, 2.1.5, with an English Translation by Sir James George Frazer, F.B.A., F.R.S. in 2 Volumes. Cambridge, MA, Harvard University Press; London, William Heinemann Ltd. 1921. Apollodorus only identified these daughters of Danaus by Phoebe and Atlantia (another hamadryad), not specifying who was the daughter of the other. These ten women joined the sons of Aegyptus who were begotten on an Arabian woman. According to Hippostratus' account, Europe, daughter of Nilus and begotten all the fifty daughters of Danaus.John Tzetzes. Chiliades, 7.37 p. 370-371 Translated by Vasiliki Dogani * Phoebe, one of the Heliades.Hyginus. Fabulae, 154; Ovid. Metamorphoses, Book 2.340 * Phoebe, a Spartan princess who was the daughter of King Tyndareus and Leda, daughter of King Thestius of Pleuron. She was the (half-)sister of Castor and Pollux, Helen, Clytemnestra, Timandra and Philonoe.Euripides. Iphigenia at Aulis, 50Ovid. Hieroides, 8.77 * Phoebe (Leucippid), daughter of Leucippus.Pseudo-Apollodorus. Bibliotheca, Book 3.11.4 * Phoebe, one of the Amazons who fought against Heracles.Diodorus Siculus. Bibliotheca Historica, Book 4.16 * Phoebe, an epithet of Artemis. Also, Phoebe is a crater on Janus (moon of Saturn), named after the character from Greek mythology. == References == Category:Hamadryad Category:Women in Greek mythology Category:Characters in Greek mythology
title: Phoebe (Greek myth)
